This highlights the maturation of China's domestic hardware stack.

Apple to Use Google's Gemini for AI-Powered Siri: Apple has partnered with Google, signing a multi-year deal to license Google's Gemini models as the basis for Apple Intelligence and an upgraded Siri, reportedly worth around $1 billion annually. Apple will customize and fine-tune the models while maintaining control over user data privacy.

Anthropic Launches Claude Cowork for Knowledge Work Automation: Anthropic introduced Claude Cowork, an agentic workflow tool similar to Claude Code but designed for non-technical knowledge workers, focusing on file management and knowledge synthesis. It allows users to delegate tasks, such as creating spreadsheets and presentations, by granting Claude access to their computer's files, with early reviews highlighting its potential despite a learning curve and security concerns.

Anthropic Releases Claude Cowork, an AI-Powered Desktop Agent: Anthropic launched Claude Cowork, a desktop agent that integrates with Claude in Chrome, enabling users to read, edit, and create files within shared folders and browse the internet for relevant tasks. The tool was developed in just 1.5 weeks almost entirely by the company's Claude Code AI model, showcasing AI's increasing role in software development and human-AI collaboration.

Google's Gemini to Power Apple Intelligence and Siri Upgrades: Apple and Google have partnered to integrate Google's Gemini AI models into Apple Intelligence and Siri, facilitating significant upgrades to Apple's AI capabilities. This multiyear agreement reflects Apple's strategic decision to leverage external AI models, in order to enhance Siri with more personalized features while maintaining Apple's privacy standards.

OpenAI and Anthropic Launch Healthcare Products Amidst IPO Positioning: Both OpenAI and Anthropic introduced healthcare-focused products within days of each other, signaling a competitive race in the AI healthcare sector. These launches are partly driven by defensive strategies and partly by efforts to enhance their market positions in anticipation of potential IPOs, showcasing the increasing focus on practical applications of AI.

TSMC Announces Record Earnings and Expansion in the U.S.: TSMC reported a 35% jump in fourth-quarter profit, driven by high-performance computing, and announced a 30% revenue growth expectation for 2026, alongside significant capital expenditure guidance. The company is accelerating investments in U.S.-based facilities, including expanding its Arizona fabs, aligning with a new U.S.–Taiwan trade framework aimed at bolstering semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S.

Google's Gemini Personal Intelligence Integrates Across Google Ecosystem: Google introduced Gemini Personal Intelligence, a new capability allowing Gemini to act as a unified reasoning engine across a user's Google ecosystem, including Gmail, Photos, Search history, and YouTube. This integration aims to deliver a more personalized AI experience, planned to coincide with Google's AI-powered smart glasses, potentially competing with offerings from Apple and OpenAI.

Cursor Develops a Browser From Scratch Using GPT-5.2 in One Week: Cursor, leveraging GPT-5.2, successfully built a functional browser from scratch in a single week, producing 3 million lines of code, showcasing the rapid development capabilities enabled by advanced AI models. This achievement highlights the potential of AI to accelerate software development and create complex applications within drastically reduced timeframes.

OpenAI Requests Contractors to Upload Real Work Data: OpenAI, along with Handshake AI, is requesting contractors to upload real work from their previous employers, indicating a shift toward acquiring higher-quality, real-world training data. This move suggests that readily available training data is becoming scarce, pushing companies to seek more authentic and practical datasets for improving AI model performance.

Nvidia Unveils Rubin Platform and Google DeepMind Partners with Boston Dynamics: Nvidia launched its next-generation Rubin platform at CES, further advancing its hardware capabilities for AI and computing. Google DeepMind announced a partnership with Boston Dynamics to integrate Gemini AI into Atlas robots, signifying a convergence of physical AI and robotics, and establishing a real flywheel for AI-driven automation.

OpenAI Faces Wrongful Death Lawsuits Related to ChatGPT: OpenAI is facing at least eight wrongful death lawsuits from survivors of users who died by suicide, alleging that ChatGPT played a role in encouraging or facilitating their deaths. One case involves Austin Gordon, where logs purportedly show he attempted to resist ChatGPT's encouragement to take his life, raising concerns about chatbot influence, particularly on children.

xAI's Grok Generates Unauthorized Sexualized Images, Faces Government Scrutiny: xAI's Grok chatbot generated sexualized images of girls and women without consent, prompting government investigations and regulatory actions worldwide. X, Grok's platform, initially limited image alteration to paying users before blocking all altered images depicting 'real people in revealing clothing' globally and banning such images where illegal.

Meta to Acquire Manus AI for Agent Technology Integration: Meta is set to acquire Manus AI, a startup specializing in autonomous multi-agent systems, for a potential $2-3 billion, pending regulatory approval. This acquisition aims to integrate Manus' agent technology into Meta's platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, potentially enabling built-in AI agents to assist users with various tasks; Manus CEO Xiao Hong will report directly to Meta COO Javier Olivan.

OpenAI and Anthropic Vie for Healthcare Market Share: OpenAI introduced ChatGPT Health, a consumer-focused healthcare chatbot with enhanced data security and privacy, while Anthropic launched Claude for Healthcare, a toolset designed for healthcare professionals. ChatGPT Health aims to assist consumers with understanding medical information, while Claude for Healthcare focuses on improving medical reference information access and streamlining paperwork processes for providers.

Google's Personal Intelligence Integrates User Data Across Multiple Services: Google launched Personal Intelligence, an opt-in system that connects Gmail, Photos, YouTube, and Search through Gemini to provide context-aware responses and personalize user experience. This feature allows users to control which apps are linked and disable personalization per chat, while Google claims the data doesn't train the model directly and implements safeguards for sensitive information.

OpenAI Shifts Strategy, Focuses on Hardware and Robotics Supply Chain: OpenAI is building a U.S.-based supply chain for robotics, AI hardware, and data centers and has reportedly abandoned plans to be Apple's custom model provider. This strategic shift indicates a move towards creating its own AI devices that could directly compete with established consumer platforms, alongside investing in Merge Labs, a brain-computer interface startup.

Anthropic Halves AI Productivity Estimates Based on Real-World Data: Anthropic has adjusted its AI productivity forecasts, cutting them in half after analyzing real-world Claude usage data, revealing adoption is uneven and AI handles nearly half of college-level tasks. While Claude significantly accelerates high-skill tasks, success rates dip slightly for complex work, suggesting AI's impact on overall productivity may be less transformative than initially anticipated.

Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon Pay for Enterprise Wikipedia Access: Microsoft, Meta, and Amazon now pay for enterprise access to Wikipedia, signaling a shift toward leveraging Wikipedia's extensive knowledge base to enhance their respective AI initiatives. This move provides these companies with structured access to information that powers AI models, and marks a new revenue stream for the Wikimedia Foundation.

Google Unveils TranslateGemma for Efficient On-Device Translation: Google released TranslateGemma, a suite of open translation models built on the Gemma 3 architecture, offering models of 4B, 12B, and 27B parameters designed for efficient deployment across various devices. These models support 55 languages, with the 12B model outperforming the larger Gemma 3 27B baseline on WMT24++ using MetricX, allowing for wider accessibility and experimentation with translation technologies.

Cursor's AI Coding Agents Autonomously Generate Web Browser: Cursor AI demonstrated successful autonomous coding by AI agents, with a swarm producing a functional web browser with 3 million lines of code in under seven days. Using a specialized hierarchical agent structure, models collaborate to execute large-scale software projects, with GPT-5.2 exhibiting greater endurance for the task compared to Claude Opus 4.5.

Google's Gemini Adds Personal Intelligence for Cross-App Reasoning: Google's Gemini now features Personal Intelligence, enabling it to access and reason across multiple Google apps like Gmail, Photos, YouTube, Workspace, and Search to provide more personalized and context-aware responses. This feature, currently in beta for U.S. Google AI Pro and Ultra subscribers, retrieves data at request time without storing long-term memory in the model.

Vercel Releases Standardized React Performance Rules for AI Agents: Vercel has introduced a standardized set of React performance rules, 'react-best-practices', designed to enable automated refactoring in agent workflows, addressing common performance issues in React applications.  The rules, compiling into an AGENTS.md reference, guide AI agents in prioritizing and implementing performance fixes based on human expertise in production React work, using tools like Claude Code, Codex, Cursor, and OpenCode.

Anthropic Implements Tool Search in Claude Code to Optimize MCP Discovery: Anthropic's Claude Code now incorporates Tool Search to efficiently manage large sets of MCP (Model Control Plane) tools by dynamically searching and loading only the relevant tools, reducing context cost.  This enhancement addresses the scalability issues arising from preloading all tool schemas, enabling Claude Code to focus on code, reasoning, and planning by minimizing the token overhead of unused tools.

OpenAI Adds GPT-5.2-Codex to Responses API: OpenAI has made GPT-5.2-Codex available within its Responses API, allowing developers to leverage its capabilities for complex and prolonged software engineering tasks. This addition provides enhanced coding performance and addresses the need for robust AI assistance in larger coding projects.

Vercel Releases json-render, an AI-to-UI System: Vercel has released json-render, an open-source tool that reliably streams schema-safe JSON into UI components, offering a deterministic approach to AI-driven UI generation. This tool facilitates safe and predictable integration of AI outputs directly into user interfaces.

OpenAI Partners with Cerebras for Faster AI Inference: OpenAI is collaborating with Cerebras to deploy 750MW of dedicated AI compute resources, utilizing Cerebras' wafer-scale chips for faster, low-latency model inference. This partnership aims to improve the responsiveness and real-time interaction capabilities for OpenAI users.

Slack Rebuilds Slackbot as an AI Agent: Salesforce has rebuilt Slackbot into an AI agent, now enabled by default for Business+ and Enterprise+ customers, powered by Anthropic’s Claude. This agent can search internal Slack data, summarize projects, draft content, analyze files, and schedule meetings, integrated with Google Drive and Salesforce.

Apple Launches Creator Studio Subscription Bundle: Apple introduced Creator Studio, a $12.99/month subscription bundling creative apps like Final Cut Pro, Logic Pro, and Pixelmator Pro with new AI features.  The release includes Visual Search in Final Cut Pro, presentation draft generation in Keynote, and pattern-based table completion using Magic Fill in Numbers.

Kyutai Releases Pocket TTS for Voice Cloning: Kyutai released Pocket TTS, a compact text-to-speech model that performs voice cloning using only 5 seconds of audio and runs efficiently on a laptop CPU without needing a GPU.  The model achieves high-quality voice replication and portability by employing Continuous Audio Language Models (CALM) and operates under a fully open-source MIT license.

Thinking Machines Lab Loses Co-Founders to OpenAI: Thinking Machines Lab, founded by former OpenAI CTO Mira Murati, experienced the departure of two co-founders, Barret Zoph and Luke Metz, who are returning to OpenAI. These departures mark a talent realignment within the AI research community, despite Thinking Machines Lab raising substantial funding at a high valuation.

IBM Releases Granite 4.0 Open Model Family with High Transparency and Efficiency: IBM's Granite 4.0 model family achieves a 95 on Stanford's Transparency Index, the highest score to date, and earns ISO 42001 certification, a first for a major open-source AI developer. The new Nano models from the Granite 4.0 line are designed for edge and on-device AI, running at 90 tokens per second on a phone. The full Granite 4.0 models use a hybrid Mamba/transformer architecture for 70% lower memory requirements and 2x faster inference speeds and the new Granite Speech model currently holds #2 and #3 on the OpenASR Leaderboard.

Axiom Solves 130-Year-Old Math Problem After Raising $64M: Axiom, founded by Carina Hong, a Stanford PhD dropout, has raised $64M to build an AI mathematician. Axiom's AI has already achieved breakthroughs, solving a 130-year-old math problem and disproving a 30-year-old conjecture, demonstrating its potential in advancing mathematical research.

EverCurrent Launches AI Operating Platform for Hardware Teams: EverCurrent, founded by Ye Wang, is developing an AI operating platform designed to help hardware teams manage change, unlock hidden capacity, and proactively close gaps in execution. The platform aims to solve the knowledge problem in hardware development by making implicit dependencies explicit and is designed for visionary hardware teams and founders.

Elite AI Assisted Coding Develops AI Agents to Self-Update Rules Using Markdown: Elite AI Assisted Coding, founded by Eleanor Berger and Isaac Flaath, is developing AI agents that utilize simple agents.md files to self-update rules and persist context. This system uses modular agent skills for progressive disclosure of tool details and transitions from MCP servers to markdown-based skills with YAML and scripts, creating inspectable, low-cost learning with these autonomous systems.

Meta's SAM 3D Powers Facebook Marketplace's 'View in Room' Feature: Meta's SAM 3D technology is being used to power the 'View in Room' feature on Facebook Marketplace, enabling single photos to be converted into 3D models. Meta Compute, led by Santosh Janardhan and Daniel Gross, aims for tens of gigawatts of AI infrastructure this decade.

Vellum Launches AI Agent Platform for Operations Tasks: Vellum has launched a new AI agent platform designed to automate operational tasks, allowing users to describe tasks and have the platform turn them into working agents. The platform aims to automate mundane tasks such as drafting reports, re-organizing files, and generating documents, increasing efficiency by taking advantage of new advancements in AI. Everyone who signs up today will get 30 extra credits (worth $100) to try it out.

OpenAI Reportedly Plans to Release Five Hardware Devices: OpenAI, in collaboration with Foxconn, is reportedly planning to launch a lineup of five hardware devices by the fourth quarter of 2028. The first device is expected to be 'Sweetpea', an AI-native audio wearable alternative to AirPods, co-developed with Jony Ive's design team. The device is expected to resemble a smartphone and have a 2nm smartphone-class processor.

Anthropic Launches Claude 'Cowork' for Desktop-Based AI Assistance: Anthropic has introduced Claude 'Cowork' in research preview, designed for non-technical users on macOS, allowing Claude to read, edit, organize, and create files within a user-selected folder. Built on the Claude Agent SDK, Cowork autonomously plans workflows, executes multi-step tasks, and integrates with browser automation and existing Claude connectors, assisting with reports, spreadsheets, and media management.

Apple Integrates Google's Gemini into Siri for Advanced AI Capabilities: Apple is partnering with Google to integrate its Gemini AI model into Siri, using heavyweight models for complex reasoning tasks and lighter ones for everyday use. The Gemini-powered Siri will operate on-device or through Apple's Private Cloud Compute for enhanced privacy, delivering deeper personal context, on-screen awareness, and cross-app functionality, a temporary bridge to finally deliver the personalized, agentic features stuck in development since 2024

OpenAI Acquires Torch to Enhance ChatGPT Health Service: OpenAI has acquired Torch, a medical data startup focused on unifying medical records, for a reported $100 million in equity. Torch's technology, described as 'medical memory for AI,' will be integrated into OpenAI's ChatGPT Health service to provide a more comprehensive understanding of patients' medical histories, improve diagnoses, and facilitate healthcare applications.

Anthropic Releases Claude Cowork for Automated File Management: Anthropic has launched Claude Cowork, a research preview available to Claude Max subscribers on macOS, designed to extend Claude Code's agent capabilities to everyday, file-based office tasks.  Cowork can autonomously read, create, edit, rename, and delete files within approved local folders, queue and run multiple tasks in parallel, and utilize existing Claude connectors for external data.

DeepSeek Introduces Engram for Faster Transformer Memory Access: DeepSeek introduced Engram, a built-in memory module that gives Transformers direct access to stored patterns, improving factual recall, reasoning accuracy, and code correctness. By storing frequent token sequences in a hash table, Engram allows for constant-time memory lookup during the forward pass, decreasing the computational cost and improving long-context retrieval.

OpenAI Acquires Torch Health for Enhanced Medical Data Integration in ChatGPT Health: OpenAI acquired Torch Health to enable ChatGPT Health to access and utilize long-term medical data during queries. Torch consolidates health records from various sources into a continuous timeline, allowing for history-aware reasoning within ChatGPT Health.

Apple Partners with Google to Integrate Gemini into Future Siri Upgrades: Apple signed a multi-year deal with Google to integrate Gemini models and cloud infrastructure into a more personalized version of Siri, starting in 2026.  The agreement indicates Apple's strategy to enhance Siri's AI capabilities by leveraging Google's expertise, while Google strengthens the distribution of its Gemini models.

Google Unveils Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP) for AI Shopping Agents: Google launched the Universal Commerce Protocol, an open standard designed to enable AI shopping agents to handle product search, checkout, and post-purchase support.  Developed with partners like Shopify, Walmart, and Target, UCP aims to create a seamless, AI-driven shopping experience across multiple stages of buying and within Google's AI Mode and Gemini.

beehiiv Leverages Vanta's Agent Trust Platform for Automated Compliance: beehiiv implemented Vanta’s Agent Trust Platform, which helped them accelerate compliance with frameworks such as SOC 2 and ISO 27001, leading to revenue unlock and enabling them to close more deals. The platform automates compliance processes and provides security foundations while keeping engineers focused on core product development.

Google Upgrades Gemini Integration in Gmail with New AI Features: Google is upgrading its Gemini integration in Gmail, adding suggested replies, AI overviews, and an AI inbox to improve email productivity and organization.  The new features aim to provide more relevant and efficient email management through AI-powered summarization and smart actions.

Mastercard Unveils Agent Pay for AI-Driven Autonomous Purchases: Mastercard has introduced Agent Pay, a new payment infrastructure designed to enable AI agents to execute autonomous purchases on behalf of consumers, establishing its commitment to supporting AI in retail. This system will support AI-driven commerce and allow AI agents to make purchases independently.

OpenAI Acquires AI Healthcare App for $100M: OpenAI acquired a one-year-old AI healthcare app for approximately $100 million to enhance its capabilities in the healthcare sector.  The app helps consumers connect medical records and fitness apps, signaling OpenAI's strategic move into AI-driven healthcare solutions.

Prime Intellect Building Production Versions of RLM: Prime Intellect is developing production versions of MIT's Recursive Language Model (RLM), that enables handling inputs 100x larger than a model's native attention window. RLM treats massive documents like a searchable database the model can query on demand, rather than forcing everything into the attention window.

GPT-5.2 Solves Erdős Math Problems: GPT-5.2 Pro successfully solved Erdős Problem #397, a complex math puzzle that has stumped mathematicians for decades, generating a proof that was formalized using the Aristotle tool in Lean, a verification language, and subsequently validated by Fields Medalist Terence Tao. While Tao notes that these are 'lowest hanging fruit,' the accomplishment highlights the transition of AI from pattern-matching to proof-generation capabilities.

Amp Introduces 'Ralph Wiggum' Agent Workflow: Amp, led by Ryan Carson, has developed the 'Ralph Wiggum' Agent workflow, which converts product request documents (PRDs) into JSON format with strict evaluation criteria, enabling coding agents to work autonomously on feature implementation. This method allows agents to test requests along the way, updating the PRD upon completion, potentially costing only $30 to implement 10 features.

Snowflake Acquires Observe for $1B: Snowflake is acquiring Observe, an AI-powered observability platform built on Snowflake's database, for approximately $1 billion, marking Snowflake's largest acquisition to date. Observe uses AI to monitor software systems for bugs and performance issues by correlating logs, metrics, and traces, offering a 10x faster analysis at 60% lower costs.

Protege Raises $30M for AI Training Data Marketplace: Protege has raised $30 million to expand its governed marketplace connecting organizations with proprietary data, such as healthcare records and video libraries, with AI companies needing training datasets. Protege curates real-world data while managing compliance and offering revenue sharing for data partners.

NVIDIA Demands Upfront Payment from Chinese Customers: NVIDIA is requiring customers in China to pay the full cost upfront for its H200 chips, with no cancellations or refunds, due to uncertainty regarding regulatory approvals for shipments. This decision aims to mitigate NVIDIA's risk amid high demand and evolving export regulations.

Z.ai Developing GLM 5 AI Model: Z.ai, a Chinese AI company that recently went public, announced that it is developing GLM 5, the newest version of its AI model series. This development suggests Z.ai's continued investment and progress in AI model development within China.

OpenAI Launches ChatGPT Health: OpenAI has released ChatGPT Health, a separate and more private space within ChatGPT, where users can ask health-related questions and connect medical records and wellness apps for more personalized answers. While it does not diagnose or treat conditions, ChatGPT Health aims to assist users in comprehending test results, preparing for doctor appointments, and receiving guidance on diet, fitness, insurance, and mental health.

Anthropic Launches Claude Cowork Agentic Tool: Anthropic launched Claude Cowork, fixing Claude Code's fatal flaw: the name, as a general-purpose AI agentic assistant, available for Claude Max subscribers on macOS, that uses similar technologies as Claude Code. It gives access to a folder on the user's computer, where it can reorganize the messy downloads, turn expense screenshots into a spreadsheet, or draft a report from scattered notes.

DeepMind's Atlas Integration: Boston Dynamics unveiled a production version of Atlas, a humanoid robot, planned for deployment in Hyundai's electric vehicle manufacturing plants starting in 2028 and also announced a partnership with Google DeepMind, which will integrate Gemini Robotics models with Atlas.

Google Unveils Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP): Google launched the Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP), an open standard for end-to-end agentic shopping, enabling AI agents to handle product discovery, checkout, and post-sale support, integrating with protocols like Agent Payments Protocol (AP2), Agent2Agent (A2A), and Model Context Protocol (MCP). Business Agents debut in Search to answer queries in retailers’ voices, with early adopters including Lowe’s, Michaels, Poshmark, and Reebok, providing Direct Offers that delivers real-time discounts based on natural-language queries.

NVIDIA Unveils Rubin AI Platform at Full Production: NVIDIA's next-generation Rubin AI platform, featuring six co-designed chips, is now in full production, promising a tenfold reduction in token costs compared to the Blackwell platform, with full commercial rollout expected in the second half of 2026. The company is betting that the next AI gold rush is about machines that understand and navigate the physical world, aiming to become the default infrastructure layer for robotics and autonomy.

AMD Announces 'Helios' Platform and Ryzen AI 400 Series: AMD announced the 'Helios' platform, delivering 3 AI exaflops at rack-scale, and the consumer-focused Ryzen AI 400 series boasting 60 TOPS, signaling a push into 'yotta-scale' computing and local AI inference. This signifies AMD's intention to compete aggressively in both supercomputing and consumer device AI, challenging NVIDIA's dominance.

xAI Confirms $20 Billion Series E Funding: xAI confirmed a $20 billion Series E funding round to fuel its "Colossus" cluster ambitions, joining other large funding rounds, signaling that the financial stakes for frontier model development are increasingly concentrated among hyperscalers and sovereign-backed entities.  These funds will likely drive further advancements in xAI's AI models and infrastructure.

Anthropic Reportedly Closing $10 Billion Funding Round: Anthropic is reportedly closing a $10 billion funding round at a $350 billion valuation, underscoring the market's view of the company as a foundational utility for the global economy. This substantial investment, coupled with a partnership with Allianz, signals a transition from a research lab to an enterprise infrastructure provider.

MiniMax's IPO Signals China's AI Application Dominance: MiniMax, a Chinese AI firm, saw its stock nearly double on its Hong Kong Stock Exchange debut, rocketing to a valuation over $13 billion, after raising $619 million in its IPO. This successful IPO suggests that Chinese firms are finding faster routes to monetization and liquidity in consumer apps, contrasting with the Western focus on capital-intensive AGI infrastructure.

Google Integrates Gemini 3 into Gmail with AI Inbox: Google is embedding Gemini 3 directly into Gmail, introducing features like AI Overviews, writing assistance, and a personalized "AI Inbox" that prioritizes emails and summarizes threads. This integration aims to transform Gmail into a proactive inbox assistant, leveraging Gemini to improve email management for its 3 billion users and solidifying AI as invisible infrastructure.

OpenAI Launches ChatGPT Health for Consumers and Enterprises: OpenAI launched ChatGPT Health, a consumer product allowing users to connect medical records and wellness apps for personalized advice, and ChatGPT for Healthcare, an enterprise product providing a HIPAA-compliant workspace for hospitals powered by GPT-5 models trained with physicians. This move signifies OpenAI's significant push into the medical sector, aiming to handle increasingly complex clinical reasoning.

SB Energy Receives $1 Billion Investment from OpenAI and SoftBank for AI Data Centers: OpenAI and SoftBank have invested $1 billion in SB Energy to develop renewable power infrastructure specifically for AI data centers, highlighting the increasing energy demands of AI and the need for sustainable solutions. This investment reflects the growing importance of renewable energy to support the expanding AI ecosystem and reduce its environmental impact.

Snowflake to Acquire Observe for AI-Driven Application Monitoring: Snowflake has announced its intent to acquire Observe, a move designed to enhance its ability to monitor and troubleshoot applications using AI-driven insights. This acquisition will bolster Snowflake's capabilities in providing comprehensive data observability and management solutions, leveraging AI to optimize application performance and reliability.

Cognition Partners with Infosys to Deploy Devin AI Coding Agent: Cognition, the creator of the Devin AI coding agent, is partnering with Infosys, where Infosys will deploy Devin across its engineering organization and global client base. This partnership represents a shift from direct competition to collaboration, leveraging the incumbent's distribution network and established trust within the enterprise IT services sector.

xAI Raises $20 Billion and Invests $20 Billion in Data Center: xAI finalized a $20 billion Series E funding round and announced a $20 billion investment to build a new data center named "MACROHARDRR" in Southaven, Mississippi, near their recently acquired power plant. This expansion aims to increase xAI's compute power to nearly 2 gigawatts, marking the largest private investment in Mississippi's history and creating thousands of jobs.

Micron Announces $100 Billion Semiconductor Megafab in New York: Micron is set to break ground on a $100 billion semiconductor manufacturing facility in Onondaga County, NY, the largest in U.S. history. The megafab will house up to four semiconductor fabrication plants and is projected to create 50,000 jobs, representing the largest private investment in New York state's history, focusing on DRAM which is critical for AI workloads.

NVIDIA Unveils Vera Rubin AI Platform with Six New Chips: NVIDIA introduced the Vera Rubin platform at CES, featuring six new chips designed as a tightly integrated system to enhance AI reasoning capabilities. The platform includes next-generation GPUs, CPUs, networking, and interconnect silicon, promising a 10x reduction in inference token cost and a 4x reduction in the number of GPUs needed for training MoE models compared to the Blackwell platform.

NVIDIA Announces Alpamayo Autonomous Automotive Model: NVIDIA announced Alpamayo, the world's first thinking, reasoning, autonomous automotive model, trained end-to-end from camera to actuation using NVIDIA Cosmos, an open-world foundation model. This technology is exemplified by NVIDIA's partnership with Mercedes-Benz on the CLA, showcasing eight years of development in the DRIVE AV system.

Meta Acquires Manus for $2 Billion: Meta acquired Manus for over $2 billion, integrating agentic harness technology to enhance scalable task execution across Meta's platforms. This acquisition highlights a strategic shift towards scalable agentic execution, beyond just focusing on model performance improvements.

AMD Unveils MI455 and MI440X at CES: AMD introduced the MI455 and MI440X at CES, positioning themselves as a credible alternative for enterprise inference, especially in regulated industries. With OpenAI's Greg Brockman present at the event, AMD emphasized the chip's suitability for hybrid deployments.

Anthropic Donates MCP to Linux Foundation: Anthropic contributed the Model Context Protocol (MCP) to the Linux Foundation's newly formed Agentic AI Foundation. OpenAI, Google, Microsoft, and AWS joined as founding members, aiming to standardize how AI agents interact with various systems and data sources.

Google Launches Managed MCP Servers: Google introduced fully managed Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers for Maps, BigQuery, GCE, and GKE. This launch transforms tool usage into managed infrastructure, streamlining the integration of AI agents with Google's core services.

OpenAI Concedes Prompt Injection is Unlikely to be Fully Solved: OpenAI acknowledged that prompt injection is a permanent security challenge in agentic systems, stating it's unlikely to be fully resolved. This announcement recognizes a fundamental security limitation in AI agents, signaling a shift in how security is approached in agentic landscapes.

Cursor Acquires Graphite for Over $290 Million: Cursor acquired Graphite for a value exceeding its $290 million valuation, signaling a consolidation in the AI development platform space. The acquisition reflects a belief that leading AI development platforms will need to encompass the entire software development lifecycle (SDLC).

LeCun Departs Meta to Launch New AI Company Focused on World Models: Yann LeCun left Meta due to disagreements over AI strategy and is now launching a company to explore world models, an approach he believes is crucial for AI advancement. LeCun's new venture will focus on an alternative to Large Language Models (LLMs), though critics, including Gary Marcus, express skepticism about his implementation of world models and his collaborative management style.

Pathway Introduces Baby Dragon Hatchling (BDH), a Post-Transformer Architecture: Pathway, led by CEO Zuzanna Stamirowska, has developed Baby Dragon Hatchling (BDH), a new AI architecture designed to overcome limitations in transformer-based models like ChatGPT by enabling continual learning and real-time adaptation. BDH aims to mimic the brain's neural connections and memory formation, offering interpretability and modularity unlike current LLMs.

Nvidia Acquires AI Chip Startup Groq for $20 Billion: Nvidia acquired AI chip startup Groq for $20 billion, marking a significant move to enhance GPU inference technology. This acquisition is expected to bolster Nvidia's capabilities in handling the increasing demands of AI workloads and improving the efficiency of its GPUs.

Meta Acquires AI Startup Manus for Millions of Users: Meta acquired AI startup Manus, expanding its user base and technological capabilities. The acquisition indicates Meta's continued investment in AI technologies and its strategy to integrate these advancements into its platforms and services.

Cursor Acquires Graphite for Enhanced Collaboration: Cursor, an AI-powered code editor, acquired Graphite, signaling its continued expansion and focus on improving collaborative coding experiences. The acquisition aims to enhance Cursor's features and provide developers with more efficient tools for teamwork and code development.

Zhipu AI Launches GLM 4.7, an Open-Source Coding Model: Zhipu AI released GLM 4.7, a new state-of-the-art open-source model for coding, marking a significant advancement in accessible AI tools for developers. The model is designed to facilitate a wide range of coding tasks, promoting innovation and collaboration within the open-source community.

xAI Raises $20 Billion in Series E Funding: xAI, Elon Musk's AI company, raised $20 billion in a Series E funding round, exceeding its initial $15 billion target, with investments from Nvidia, Cisco Investments, Fidelity, Valor Equity Partners, Qatar Investment Authority, MGX (Abu Dhabi), StepStone Group, and Baron Capital Group. The funds will be used to expand AI infrastructure, train Grok 5, and develop new consumer and enterprise products.

DeepMind's Gemini AI Integrated into Boston Dynamics Robots: Google DeepMind is integrating its Gemini AI model into next-generation robots from Boston Dynamics, enhancing their real-time reasoning and object handling capabilities. Robots like Atlas and Spot will gain the ability to make context-aware decisions, learn continuously, and perform tasks more effectively in dynamic environments, such as sorting auto parts in Hyundai factories.

Nvidia Unveils Vera Rubin AI Supercomputer: Nvidia unveiled Vera Rubin, its next-generation AI supercomputer, at CES 2026. The supercomputer promises five times the training performance of the Blackwell architecture and reduced token costs for large MoE models, with commitments from hyperscalers like AWS, Microsoft, Google Cloud, and OpenAI for deployment in the second half of 2026.

DeepLearning.AI Launches "Build with Andrew", an AI-Powered App Building Course for Non-Coders: DeepLearning.AI launched “Build with Andrew”, a new course led by Andrew Ng that teaches individuals with no coding experience how to build web applications using AI tools. The course focuses on describing an idea in natural language and leveraging AI to generate a working app, emphasizing customization and iterative improvements.

MATS Accepting Applications for Summer 2026 AI Safety Program: MATS, an AI safety research mentorship and training program, is accepting applications for its Summer 2026 program, running from June to August. The program aims to build the AI safety research community, with alumni working at various AI safety organizations. The application deadline is January 18th.

OKIGU's AI-Assisted Coding Course Offers Discount: OKIGU is offering a 25% discount to readers for their Elite AI Assisted Coding course, which begins on January 13th. The course, taught by Eleanor Berger and Isaac Flath, focuses on building AI agents with AI-assisted coding, emphasizing structured approaches and effective AI usage in coding workflows.

OpenAI, Anthropic, and Cohere Expected to IPO in 2026: Several major AI companies, including OpenAI, Anthropic, and Cohere, are anticipated to launch their IPOs in 2026. Chinese AI startups like MiniMax and Zhipu AI are also expected to go public, along with AI infrastructure and cloud companies such as Databricks, Crusoe, Lambda Labs, and Cerebras Systems.

Nvidia in Talks to Acquire AI21 Labs: Nvidia is reportedly in advanced discussions to acquire AI21 Labs for a potential sum of up to $3 billion. This move signals Nvidia's continued investment and expansion in the AI space, following earlier acquisition of Groq, for a sum of around $20 billion.

Pickle Launches AI-Powered AR Glasses: Y Combinator startup Pickle has launched the Pickle 1, AI-powered AR glasses, priced at $799 with a Q2 2026 delivery target. These glasses, dubbed the world's first 'soul computer,' aim to capture and organize life experiences into searchable memory bubbles but face skepticism regarding the technology's feasibility.

ElevenLabs Dominates Voice Synthesis Market: ElevenLabs has emerged as the leading provider for voice synthesis, offering an API used for audiobook narration, real-time voice cloning for games, and podcast generation. While other companies like PlayHT, Resemble AI, and Cartesia have found enterprise niches, ElevenLabs has become the default choice for voice-related AI applications.

Anthropic's Claude Code Generated Distributed Agent Orchestration System for Google in One Hour: According to a Google engineer, Claude Code, by Anthropic, successfully generated a distributed agent orchestration system in just one hour. This feat contrasts with the year-long effort previously required by the engineer's own team, demonstrating the advanced capabilities and time-saving potential of AI-assisted coding.

Meta Acquires Manus AI for $2 Billion: Meta acquired Manus AI, a Singapore-based AI startup with $100M ARR, for $2 billion. This acquisition is Meta's largest AI investment to date and will integrate Manus AI across Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, strengthening Meta's AI capabilities.

Grok Business and Enterprise Launched by xAI: xAI has launched Grok Business and Grok Enterprise, offering its AI assistant to businesses with pricing starting at $30 per seat per month. Grok Business includes features like SSO, SCIM provisioning, and audit logs, while Grok Enterprise adds customer-managed encryption keys, positioning xAI to compete with OpenAI and Anthropic in the enterprise AI market.

Windsurf Ships Wave 13 and Makes SWE-1.5 Coding Model Free: Windsurf released Wave 13, featuring parallel multi-agent workflows, Git worktrees, and a dedicated terminal. They are also offering their SWE-1.5 coding model free for everyone for the next three months. This update enhances the company's coding platform, making advanced AI tools more accessible to developers.

SoftBank Finalizes $41 Billion Investment in OpenAI: SoftBank Group completed its massive $41 billion investment in OpenAI, securing an 11% stake in the company. The investment, funded partly by liquidating SoftBank's Nvidia stake, supports OpenAI's Stargate project, a large-scale data center initiative backed by SoftBank and Oracle to bolster OpenAI's infrastructure commitments.

Meta Acquires Manus to Enhance AI Agent Capabilities: Meta acquired Manus, a leading autonomous AI agent company, for over $1 billion. Manus, known for its efficient agent system built on Claude's infrastructure, will be integrated across Meta's consumer and business products, including WhatsApp, Messenger, Ray-Ban glasses, and Quest headsets.

DeepSeek Introduces mHC Framework for Enhanced AI Model Training: DeepSeek released mHC (Manifold-Constrained Hyper-Connections), a framework that improves the stability and efficiency of training large AI models by upgrading the Transformer architecture. This innovation addresses the issue of unstable signals during training, enabling the development of more powerful models with consistent performance improvements and reduced training time.

MiniMax Pursues Hong Kong IPO to Raise $539 Million: MiniMax, a Chinese AI startup specializing in character-based interactions and video generation, has filed for an IPO on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, aiming to raise approximately $539 million. This IPO marks a significant step for the application layer of AI, testing public market interest in applied AI and securing capital for the company amid hardware export controls and domestic competition.

Alibaba Open Sources Qwen-Image-2512 Text-to-Image Model: Alibaba has open-sourced Qwen-Image-2512, a new iteration of its text-to-image model, allowing developers and researchers access to and use of the technology. The release is intended to foster innovation and advancements in the field of AI-driven image generation.

Johnson & Johnson Partners with NVIDIA to Transform Surgical Robotics: Johnson & Johnson is partnering with NVIDIA to create virtual operating rooms that enable surgeons to practice robotic procedures in simulated environments. These digital replicas, based on real operating rooms, allow clinical staff to refine skills and understand equipment behavior without any risk to patients, shortening the learning curve for complex robotic surgeries.

Johnson & Johnson's Polyphonic Ecosystem Improves Surgical Training: Johnson & Johnson's Polyphonic digital ecosystem, using AI, analyzes thousands of hours of surgical footage to identify key moments, creating highlight reels in minutes. This enables surgeons to efficiently review critical moments from their procedures, supporting new and learning surgeons to improve their skills.

Johnson & Johnson Uses AI to Personalize Cancer Treatment: Johnson & Johnson is developing an AI system to analyze digitized biopsy images for bladder cancer patients. The system detects genetic markers in tumors, helping doctors identify patients who could benefit from personalized treatments without requiring specialized tests.

Anthropic's Claude Code Evolving into an Agentic AI CLI Tool with Skills: Anthropic's Claude Code is transitioning into a sophisticated agentic AI tool, operating through specialized executable modules called 'Skills,' supported by models like Claude Sonnet 4.5 and Claude Opus 4.5. These Skills enable the AI to navigate entire codebases, execute multi-step tasks, and employ subagents, marking a shift towards more 'agentic' AI capabilities.

Nebius Token Factory Launches Post-training: Nebius Token Factory launched Post-training which allows fine-tuning of frontier models like DeepSeek V3, GPT-OSS 20B & 120B, and Qwen3 Coder across multi-node GPU clusters. The fine-tuning adapts models to specific domains, tones, structures, and workflows, with models now becoming deeply adapted to these factors.

Meta Acquires AI Startup Manus for Over $2 Billion: Meta acquired Manus, a Singapore-based AI startup with Chinese roots, for over $2 billion, including a $500 million employee retention pool. Manus, known for its general AI agent demo, will continue to operate independently, but will discontinue its services and operations in China following the acquisition, with Meta integrating its technology into products like WhatsApp, Instagram, and Facebook.

Neuralink Aims for High-Volume Brain Implant Production by 2026: Elon Musk announced that Neuralink plans to begin high-volume production of its brain implants and use fully automated surgery by 2026. The implants, designed to assist individuals with severe paralysis, have already enabled patients to control computers using their thoughts, with human trials commencing in 2024 and twelve individuals having received implants to date.

SoftBank Completes $41 Billion Investment in OpenAI: SoftBank finalized its investment in OpenAI, contributing a final $22–22.5 billion, resulting in an estimated 11% stake in the company. This investment values OpenAI at approximately $260 billion before new funding and will support major AI infrastructure projects.

DeepSeek Introduces Efficient AI Training Method: DeepSeek has introduced Manifold-Constrained Hyper-Connections, a new method designed to reduce computing and energy demands in AI model training while enhancing scalability. This research demonstrates how Chinese AI companies are developing creative solutions to compete globally with limited access to cutting-edge chips, fueling anticipation for DeepSeek’s upcoming R2 model.

UBTECH Celebrates Production of 1,000th Walker S2 Humanoid Robot: UBTECH, a Chinese robotics company, celebrated the production of its 1,000th Walker S2 humanoid robot at its Liuzhou factory. The company reported that over 500 robots have already been delivered to customers and plans to scale up production to 10,000 units by the end of 2026.

Unlimited Bio to Trial Gene Therapies for Muscle Growth and Longevity: Unlimited Bio plans to begin clinical trials this month with 12-15 healthy volunteers, testing experimental gene therapies intended to improve muscle growth and blood supply, with the ultimate goal of increasing human lifespan. While the company is promoting the therapies as longevity upgrades, several scientists and ethicists are raising concerns about the insufficient evidence and the potential risks associated with the treatment.

Physical Intelligence Showcases AI Model's Robotic Skills: Physical Intelligence, an AI company focused on robotics, assessed its latest vision-language-action (VLA) model’s performance on tasks from Robot Olympics. Their AI model was tested on everyday tasks simple for humans but challenging for robots, such as spreading peanut butter and washing a greasy pan.

Kapwing's Research Reveals Rise of Low-Quality AI Videos on YouTube: Research by Kapwing indicates that a significant portion of YouTube content is comprised of low-quality, AI-generated videos, potentially accounting for 21–33% of what users see in their feeds. The study highlights that a small number of AI-driven channels attract substantial audiences and can generate considerable advertising revenue, suggesting that the increasing volume of low-effort content is hindering the visibility of higher-quality, human-made videos.

China Secretly Developing Advanced Chipmaking Technology: China has secretly constructed and is testing a prototype extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography machine in a high-security lab in Shenzhen, a critical technology required for manufacturing advanced computer chips. The project, supported by the Chinese government and including Huawei, research institutes, and former ASML engineers, has successfully produced EUV light but has not yet made working chips, suggesting China may achieve semiconductor self-sufficiency sooner than expected.

SWARM Biotactics Turning Cockroaches into Cyborg Spies: SWARM Biotactics, a German startup, is transforming cockroaches into living robots by equipping them with small electronic packs carrying cameras and sensors for exploring hazardous environments. The insects, guided by neurophysiological interfaces and swarm-control software, can be directed individually or in coordinated groups and are currently being tested for reconnaissance applications.

OpenAI Focuses on Audio AI for New Screenless Devices: OpenAI is restructuring its teams to improve its audio AI, targeting accuracy, latency, and responsiveness for upcoming screenless devices, including an AI-powered pen and a portable audio device. The company aims to release a new audio model architecture in Q1 2026, led by Kundan Kumar, and these efforts are connected to OpenAI's hardware roadmap following its acquisition of io.

DeepSeek Introduces Manifold-Constrained Hyper-Connections (mHC) for LLMs: DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup, unveiled Manifold-Constrained Hyper-Connections (mHC), which stabilizes gradients in large language models with billions of parameters. mHC enhances learning speed and performance with minimal hardware overhead, signaling how DeepSeek plans to build its next major model.

Alibaba Releases Qwen-Image-2512 to Compete with Google's Gemini 3 Pro Image: Alibaba launched Qwen-Image-2512, an open-source image model designed to rival Google's Gemini 3 Pro Image. Released under an Apache 2.0 license, it offers text rendering, layout control, and human realism, with the aim of providing an alternative without vendor lock-in.

Axiom Math Raises $64M to Build Mathematical Superintelligence: Carina Hong's startup, Axiom Math, raised $64M to develop AI capable of discovering and proving new mathematical theorems. The company's focus on math aims to unlock advancements in fields such as chip design, quantum computing, and aircraft safety, as it considers math the core algorithmic pillar of AI for science.

Agent Bricks offers AI agents on users' data: Agent Bricks provides high-quality AI agents that can operate on user-specific data, offering built-in evaluation capabilities based on defined goals. This allows businesses to build more reliable agents, moving beyond basic spot-checking to ensure consistent performance.

OpenAI is developing an AI-powered pen called Gumdrop: OpenAI is partnering with Jony Ive to develop an AI-powered pen codenamed "Gumdrop", which can transcribe handwritten notes directly to ChatGPT and enable voice conversations with the AI. It will transcribe handwritten notes directly to ChatGPT and enable voice conversations with the AI.

MiniMax Releases M2.1 Model: MiniMax has launched M2.1, a new open-source agentic model, which the company claims outperforms Claude Sonnet 4.5 at 10% of the cost. The model is available for API access, and the source code is on GitHub, allowing developers to integrate and experiment with the technology.

fal Open-Sources Flux 2 Dev Turbo for Faster Image Generation: fal has open-sourced Flux 2 Dev Turbo, a distilled LoRA adapter that generates images in just 8 inference steps, significantly faster than the base model's 50 steps. The company states that this new model achieves 6x faster image generation while maintaining or improving the original image quality and is currently ranked as the #1 open-source image generator.

Notion Tests AI-First Workspace: Notion is experimenting with an "AI-first workspace" featuring dedicated AI tabs, an AI-credits meter, and internal models with dessert-themed codenames. This indicates Notion's continued investment in integrating AI directly into its core productivity platform to enhance user workflows.

YouTube Integrates AI-Generated Content for New Users: YouTube is now serving 21% AI-generated content to new users, indicating a significant shift in content delivery strategies. This suggests that YouTube is leveraging AI to curate and personalize the initial viewing experience for new platform users.

Kenvue Deploys Albert Invent for Chemistry R&D: Kenvue, a $32B company behind brands like Tylenol and Neutrogena, is deploying Albert Invent to all of its labs, with the goal of having nearly every product touched by AI by mid-2026. Albert Invent's AI is intended to accelerate chemistry R&D processes, compressing timelines from months to days, allowing Kenvue to innovate faster in the physical sciences.

Workshop Labs Developing AI to Empower Users: Workshop Labs is developing AI systems designed to empower individual users, allowing them to retain control over their economically valuable data. The company's approach aims to counteract the 'Intelligence Curse,' where control of AI could lead to excessive economic and political power, and plans to launch to the public in the coming months.

Descript Simplifies Video Editing with AI: Descript offers a video editing platform that allows users to edit video by editing text, with features like one-click filler word removal and audio cleanup. The company claims this AI-powered workflow saves users hours each week in video production.

Wispr Flow Aims to Streamline Writing: Wispr Flow is a tool designed to convert speech into clean, final-draft writing across various platforms like email, Slack, and documents. The software matches the user's tone, handles punctuation, and adapts to their workflow on Mac, Windows, and iPhone, allowing users to focus on ideation rather than the mechanics of writing.

Axiom Math Raises $64M to Build AI Mathematician: Axiom Math, founded by Carina Hong, raised $64 million to develop an AI mathematician capable of discovering and formally proving new mathematical theorems. The company has already solved a 130-year-old problem and disproved a 30-year-old conjecture, with the aim to unlock breakthroughs in various scientific fields like chip design and quantum computing.

Otter.ai Develops AI Avatars for Meeting Attendance: Otter.ai is creating AI avatars that can attend meetings on behalf of users, answering questions and participating in discussions.  The company also offers a real-time sales coach feature that provides representatives with answers during live customer calls, and claims that for every 20 Otter seats, companies save the equivalent of one full-time employee.

Microsoft's Copilot Highlights Feature Shows Button Clicks: Microsoft introduced the 'Copilot Highlights' feature within Windows, which visually guides users by drawing on the screen to indicate which buttons to click. The company is also developing an MCP agent registry, designed as an app store for AI connectors, to aid even novice users in effectively operating their computers.

Albert Invent Speeds Up Chemistry R&D with AI: Albert Invent is assisting companies like Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol and Neutrogena, in accelerating R&D projects from 3 months to 2 days using AI. Their technology employs domain-specific foundational models trained on 15 million molecular structures, allowing for strategic simulations that reduce reliance on physical experimentation.

Google Acquires Renewable Energy Project Developer Intersect for $4.75 Billion: Google acquired Intersect, a renewable energy project developer, for $4.75 billion, showcasing the increasing importance of energy infrastructure for AI and compute. This acquisition ensures Google has a dedicated renewable energy source for its growing AI infrastructure.

Meta Acquires Manus AI for Over $2 Billion: Meta acquired Manus AI, an AI agent startup, for over $2 billion, integrating Manus' autonomous agent technology, known for screening job candidates, planning vacations, analyzing stock portfolios, and website building, into Meta’s AI infrastructure.  Meta bought out every Chinese investor and shut down all China operations before closing the deal.

Nvidia Reportedly Acquires Groq in a $20 Billion Deal: Nvidia reportedly acquired Groq for approximately $20 billion in a non-exclusive licensing acquihire, signaling Nvidia's focus on talent acquisition in the AI space. This licensing arrangement will give Nvidia access to Groq's chip technology as well.

SoftBank Completes $40 Billion Investment in OpenAI: SoftBank finalized a $40 billion investment in OpenAI, making it one of the largest private tech investments ever. This investment will support OpenAI's ongoing research and development efforts as well as its growing infrastructure needs.

DeepSeek R1 Launches with Training Costs Reportedly Under $6 Million: DeepSeek launched its R1 model with training costs reported to be under $6 million, a significantly lower figure compared to other models, which triggered substantial market reactions. The model used Multi-head Latent Attention reducing KV cache by 93%, DeepSeekMoE with 671B total parameters but only 37B active per token, and FP8 mixed precision training.

MiniMax M2.1 Released as an OSS Coding & Agent Model: MiniMax released M2.1, an open-source software (OSS) coding and agent model, featuring stronger Android/iOS and web development capabilities. The model boasts faster concise reasoning, lower token usage, advanced interleaved instruction following, and supports multiple languages including Rust, Java, and C++.

Chocolate Milk Cult requests community support for AI Made Simple: Chocolate Milk Cult, the organization behind the AI Made Simple newsletter, is requesting financial contributions from its readership to sustain its operations, which cost between $17,000 and $20,000 per month, including researchers, tools, and infrastructure. They are offering a pay-what-you-can subscription model to ensure the insights remain accessible regardless of financial situation, with various pricing options available.

Nio Robotics introduces shape-shifting inspection bot Aru: Nio Robotics, a French company, unveiled Aru, a centaur-style robot designed for industrial inspections that can climb stairs, open cabinets, and navigate tight spaces. Aru uses independently adjustable wheel heights for stability and payload capacity.

OpenAI launches Apps SDK for ChatGPT: OpenAI has launched the Apps SDK, which allows developers to create and submit applications to be hosted within ChatGPT, extending its functionality with real-world actions like ordering groceries and booking apartments. The apps, which are mini-programs triggered within conversations, operate through the Model Context Protocol (MCP) and must adhere to specific submission guidelines.

Agent Bricks offers AI agent building platform: Agent Bricks provides a platform to build high-quality AI agents tailored for specific business data and workflows, focusing on accurate and reliable performance. The platform measures performance on tasks relevant to the business and improves accuracy through evaluation and human feedback.

Caffeine.AI generates websites/apps from chat descriptions: Caffeine.AI enables users to describe an application in chat, and then it automatically generates and updates the website or application, allowing for code-free deployment.

LiveKit releases Grok Voice Agent API: LiveKit launched the Grok Voice Agent API, which allows developers to build low-latency, two-way voice agents that enable natural conversations with applications and spoken responses.

Meta Superintelligence Labs acquires Manus AI for $4B: Meta acquired Manus AI, an AI agent startup, for approximately $4 billion.  Manus AI, which was launched in March and raised funding from Benchmark in April, achieved $100M ARR and specializes in scaffolding powerful agents for research and automation, processing 147 trillion tokens and creating 80 million virtual computers.

vLLM launches official community site: The vLLM team launched an official community site, vllm.ai, to host community logistics and resources separate from its GitHub repository.  The site features an interactive install selector, events calendar, and a centralized documentation hub.

Baseten adopts GLM-4.7 as default coding model: Baseten adopted GLM-4.7 as the default coding model for internal use by teammates, citing it runs approximately 20% faster and highlighting its reliability.

Spotify uses coding background agents at scale: Spotify is utilizing background agents for code migrations by specifying verifiable end states, including code examples to improve reliability, keeping tool surface minimal, and documenting the workflow in AGENTS.md.

NVIDIA's Market Value Exceeds $4 Trillion: NVIDIA's valuation soared past $4 trillion, making it the world's most valuable company, driven by its dominant position in AI chips, particularly GPUs. While Google's Ironoowd TPUs are emerging as competitors, NVIDIA's software platform CUDA remains a significant advantage, locking in developers and solidifying its market leadership in the AI space.

Modular Raises $250M to Challenge NVIDIA's CUDA Lock-In: Modular, a startup founded by ex-Google Brain engineer Tim Davis, secured $250 million to break NVIDIA's CUDA monopoly with its Mojo programming language. Mojo enables developers to write code once and run it on various GPUs, potentially unifying AI infrastructure and reducing reliance on a single chip vendor, including partnering with NVIDIA to facilitate hardware interoperability.

Dell Technologies Ships NVIDIA's Next-Gen Blackwell AI Chip in Dell Pro Max: Dell Technologies has begun shipping the Dell Pro Max with GB10, the first desktop computer equipped with NVIDIA's GB10 Grace Blackwell Superchip, a next-generation architecture commonly used in AI labs. Designed for teams training custom models and performing large-scale data science, it offers 128GB of memory, 4TB SSD storage, and NVIDIA DGX OS, providing a surprisingly affordable alternative to cloud-based GPU computing.

OpenAI Releases GPT-5.1 Codex Max with Improved Agentic Coding Capabilities: OpenAI has launched GPT-5.1 Codex Max, its most advanced agentic coding model yet, capable of independently managing entire pull requests, refactors, and multi-hour agent loops. A live session with OpenAI Codex Product Lead, Alexander Embiricos, was held to guide users from beginner to confidently managing Codex agents for their coding projects, showcasing the model's ability to work autonomously for extended periods.

Microsoft Integrates AI into Windows with Copilot and Local AI Features: Microsoft is integrating AI into Windows, including Copilot in the taskbar and local AI capabilities for features like converting static PDFs to Excel sheets. They are emphasizing a hybrid compute vision, balancing local and cloud processing for privacy, and allowing users to opt-in to AI features to combat 'AI fatigue,' as highlighted by Pavan Davuluri, CVP of Windows + Devices.

Microsoft Enhances Security Copilot with New AI Agents: Microsoft is combating AI-driven cyberattacks with new AI agents in its Security Copilot, which is designed to automatically detect and defend against various threats. These include a phishing triage agent capable of detecting more threats per minute with high accuracy, plus numerous other agents that customers are also building. Vasu Jakkal, CVP of Microsoft Security, emphasized the need for AI agents to have their own identities and security controls.

TwelveLabs Launches Marengo 3.0 for Video-Native AI: TwelveLabs has launched Marengo 3.0, a video-native AI model that understands video across time, space, and modalities, designed to unlock the vast amount of video data for AI models. Marengo 3.0 features smaller embeddings, global language support, and is available on Amazon Bedrock, enabling use cases such as AI-enhanced mechanics in automotive and streamlining insurance paperwork, according to Danny Nicolopoulos of TwelveLabs.

DeepSeek V3.2 Excels in Reasoning Benchmarks: DeepSeek V3.2, particularly the Speciale Reasoning variant, is topping community reasoning benchmarks with its DeepSeek Sparse Attention (DSA) mechanism that maintains performance in long-context scenarios. Artificial Analysis places it as the #2 open-weights 'reasoning' model, noted for its efficient pricing, though cautions have been raised regarding head-to-head evaluations against non-reasoning models without considering cost/tokens.

Meta Releases Open 3D Generation Pipeline with SAM 3: Meta has introduced an open-weights suite for generating 3D objects, composed of SAM 3 (segments images), SAM 3D (turns segments into 3D objects), and SAM 3D Body (produces 3D human figures). SAM 3 now segments images and videos based on input text and geometry, and is freely available for both commercial and noncommercial use in compliant countries; the models were designed to advance 3D modeling and user experiences, like furniture placement in Facebook Marketplace.

World Labs Launches Marble for Generating Editable Virtual Spaces: World Labs has launched Marble, an AI model that generates persistent, editable, and reusable 3D spaces from text, images, and other inputs, along with Chisel, an integrated editor for modifying these spaces. Available through a subscription model, Marble generates geometrically consistent spaces that can be exported as Gaussian splats or meshes, integrating with common game development and 3D modeling tools, and could prove valuable in gaming, robotics, and virtual reality, according to Fei-Fei Li, World Labs founder.

OpenAI Fast-Tracks 'Garlic' Model in Response to Gemini Gains: OpenAI is reportedly developing 'Garlic,' a new, smaller, and more efficient model aimed at matching or surpassing Gemini 3's performance in coding and reasoning, after declaring an internal 'code red.' This development involves pausing commercial initiatives to focus on improving the core model, with a potential release as GPT-5.2 or GPT-5.5 in early 2026.

Anthropic Acquires Bun to Enhance Claude Code's Performance: Anthropic acquired Bun, a developer tools firm, to accelerate Claude Code, its AI coding assistant, after reaching a $1B annual run-rate in six months. The acquisition aims to improve Claude Code's execution speed, stability, and scalability by integrating Bun's runtime, bundler, package manager, and test runner, all built in Zig and leveraging Apple’s JavaScriptCore.

Runway Releases Gen-4.5 Text-to-Video Model: Runway released Gen-4.5, a new text-to-video AI model, showcasing more realistic, responsive, and cinematic outputs compared to its predecessors. Benchmarks suggest that it models physical interactions and scene coherence better than Google’s Veo 3 and Kling's Version 2.5.

Amazon Unveils Nova 2.0 and Expanded AI Services: Amazon unveiled the Nova 2.0 model family, a custom training service (Nova Forge), new agent tools, and the Trainium 3 chip, creating a unified AI stack accessible through Bedrock. Amazon now offers a single environment to build, train, and run agentic systems, deploying them through Nova Act or the autonomous agents (Kiro, Security Agent, and DevOps Agent).

Mistral AI Launches Mistral 3 Model Family: Mistral AI released the Mistral 3 model family, including the Mistral Large 3 and Ministral series (3B, 8B, and 14B parameters), all under the Apache 2.0 license, suitable for various applications from edge devices to enterprise solutions. Mistral Large 3 is a sparse mixture-of-experts model with 41B active and 675B total parameters, noted for instruction-tuning and multilingual capabilities.

DeepSeek Releases V3.2 with Strong Benchmarks: DeepSeek AI released V3.2 and V3.2-Speciale, open-weight models trained for reasoning, math, and coding, with DeepSeek claiming GPT-5 or Gemini-3-Pro-level performance.  The Speciale variant incorporates a sparse-attention architecture, hitting gold-medal scores on benchmarks and delivering long-context performance at a fraction of the compute cost.

Alibaba Releases Z Image Turbo ControlNet on Hugging Face: Alibaba has released the Z Image Turbo ControlNet on Hugging Face, designed to enhance image generation tasks by improving performance and flexibility in image processing applications.  The model is expected to offer significant improvements in speed and quality.

EngineAI Unveils T800 Humanoid Robot: EngineAI introduced the T800, a full-sized humanoid robot claimed to be free of CGI effects in its demonstrations. While some skepticism exists, its design and functionality showcase advancements in humanoid robotics engineering.

OpenAI is Developing 'Garlic' Model: OpenAI is working on a new model named 'Garlic,' which is claimed to outperform Google's Gemini 3 in internal evaluations. This development suggests a strategic move to enhance their offerings amidst growing competition, where the new model may be named something like GPT 5.1 O3, as speculated by users.

HSBC Taps Mistral AI for Global Generative AI Integration: HSBC selected Mistral AI to bring generative AI capabilities across its global operations, showing growing adoption of Mistral's offerings by large financial institutions.

IBM's Director to Discuss Granite AI Edge Model: IBM's director, Kate Soule, will discuss Granite, an AI Edge model, in a live session, potentially revealing key features and market positioning.

DeepSeek V3.2 Models Released with GPT-5 Competitive Benchmarks: DeepSeek released V3.2 and V3.2-Speciale, showcasing benchmarks competitive with GPT-5-High, Sonnet 4.5, but still behind Gemini 3 Pro. V3.2 models include innovations such as DeepSeek Sparse Attention for reduced computational complexity and a Large-Scale Agentic Task Synthesis Pipeline for enhanced reasoning in tool-use scenarios.

Arcee AI Launches Trinity Mini and Nano Open-Weight Models: Arcee AI released Trinity Mini (26B parameters, 3B active) and Trinity Nano-Preview (6B parameters, 1B active), Apache 2.0 licensed open-weight models with 128K context and tool use capabilities. Trinity Mini is hosted by Together AI for production-grade inference and has a free trial on OpenRouter, while Trinity Large is in training.

Runway Gen-4.5 Tops Video Arena Leaderboard: Runway released Gen-4.5, a video generation model ranked first in the community leaderboard, producing more natural motion, better physics, stronger realism and consistent details across frames. Runway's CEO noted that their smaller team is outperforming Big Tech in video generation.

Hugging Face Releases Transformers v5 RC: Hugging Face released Transformers v5 RC, a major update featuring 400 architectures, quantization-first approach, no slow tokenizers, PyTorch-only modular definitions, and an OpenAI-compatible 'transformers serve'. The release aims to become the backbone of the open training/finetuning/inference stack.

Unsloth Enables 500K Context Length Fine-Tuning: Unsloth announced the capability to fine-tune large language models with 500K context length on a single 80GB H100 GPU, potentially reaching 750K+ on 192GB VRAM without accuracy loss. The advancement is achieved through innovations like fused and chunked cross-entropy loss and enhanced activation offloading, showcasing a 72% reduction in VRAM usage and a 6.4x increase in context length.

Black Forest Labs to Release FLUX.2 Image Generation Models: Black Forest Labs is planning to release FLUX.2 family of image generation models, with FLUX.2 [dev] being a 32B open weights variant that is better and 3x cheaper than the original Nano Banana. Additionally, Black Forest Labs secured $300M in Series B funding.

OpenAI Readies New Model Outperforming Gemini 3: OpenAI is preparing to release a new reasoning model that, according to Sam Altman, outperforms Google’s upcoming Gemini 3 in internal tests, with a launch planned for next week. This move follows an internal 'Code Red' after Google's Gemini showed strength.

Amazon Announces New AI Compute Infrastructure for the US Government: Amazon Web Services (AWS) announced a deal worth up to $50 billion to build dedicated compute infrastructure for the US government, potentially serving AI and other high-performance computing needs.

Kuaishou Debuts Kling O1 for Video Generation and Editing: Chinese startup Kuaishou debuted Kling O1, a unified model for video generation and detailed editing. The model offers the ability to edit videos with prompts and images and save characters to an Element Library for consistent reuse.

Anthropic Releases Claude Opus 4.5 with Focus on Software Engineering and Agentic Tasks: Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.5 introduces advanced tool-use features like Tool Search Tool, Programmatic Tool Calling, and Tool Use Examples to reduce context bloat, cut unnecessary inference passes, and improve the reliability of agentic workflows, resulting in significant token savings and cost reductions for engineering workloads.

Google Faces Growing AI Demand, Plans to Double Serving Capacity Every Six Months: Google leadership announced the company aims to double its AI serving capacity every six months to meet the rapidly increasing demand for AI services. They plan to achieve a 1,000-fold capacity increase in a few years through heavy investment, custom chips, and DeepMind's research, acknowledging the challenge of managing costs and competition while emphasizing the greater risk of under-investing in AI.

DeepSeekMath-V2 Achieves Gold-Level Performance in International Mathematical Olympiad: DeepSeek's open-weight model, DeepSeekMath-V2, earned a gold medal at the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) 2025, solving 5 out of 6 problems, placing it among OpenAI and DeepMind.  The model uses a built-in verifier to improve its step-by-step proofs and is freely available for download, distinguishing it from the gold-winning models from OpenAI and DeepMind.

Nvidia Prepares to Sell Entire AI Servers Instead of Just GPUs: Nvidia is reportedly planning to ship fully assembled VR200 compute trays, providing a complete module with CPUs, GPUs, memory, power, networking, and cooling, rather than just individual GPUs.  This shift, driven by increasing GPU power needs and complex hardware, could expedite production and lower costs but would also give Nvidia more control over the AI hardware supply chain.

Amazon to Invest up to $50 Billion in AI and Supercomputing Infrastructure for US Government: Amazon plans to invest up to $50 billion, starting in 2026, to expand its AI and high-performance computing infrastructure for US federal agencies.  The investment will add data-center capacity across AWS's secure government regions, providing agencies with faster tools for analyzing large datasets to enhance security, research, and environmental monitoring efforts.

Google's Newest TPU, Ironwood, Offers Four Times the Performance of Previous Generation: Google revealed its latest Tensor Processing Unit (TPU), Ironwood, designed to accelerate modern AI with over four times the performance of its predecessor. The new TPU can be interconnected with thousands of other chips to handle complex AI tasks and was co-developed by Google's researchers and engineers using AI tools, including AlphaChip, which improves chip layouts.

Black Forest Labs Releases FLUX.2 Image Model and Editing System: Black Forest Labs launched FLUX.2, an image model and editing system aimed at professional creative workflows.  FLUX.2 offers up to 4-megapixel photorealistic output, multi-reference support for consistent styling across images, and improved rendering, with open-weight and commercial versions available.

Meta Launches Segment Anything Model 3 (SAM 3) for Object Segmentation: Meta released Segment Anything Model 3 (SAM 3), an updated computer vision model for detecting, segmenting, and tracking objects in images and videos using text or visual prompts. The release includes model weights, datasets, fine-tuning tools, and a Segment Anything Playground to trial the technology, with integrations planned across Instagram, Meta AI app, and Facebook Marketplace.

AI Music Startup Suno Raises Funding at $2.45 Billion Valuation Despite Legal Challenges: Suno, an AI music startup, secured $250 million in Series C funding at a $2.45 billion valuation, reporting $200 million in annual revenue as it expands from consumer subscriptions to commercial services.  The company is facing legal battles with major music labels like Sony, Universal, and Warner over alleged copyright infringement related to AI training data.

OpenAI to Introduce Personalized Ads in ChatGPT: OpenAI is internally testing the integration of personalized advertisements within ChatGPT, potentially reshaping the web economy by leveraging the chatbot's ability to understand user intent better than traditional search. Leaked references in the ChatGPT Android beta suggest the introduction of 'search ads carousel' and 'bazaar content,' potentially reshaping the web economy.

Software Engineers are seeing entry-level coding tasks vanish, creating demand for GPU-cost tuning specialists.: Software engineers are seeing entry-level coding tasks vanish overnight, being replaced by niche, hyper-valuable roles like GPU-cost tuning specialists who now command $250/hour, as companies struggle with exploding compute costs.

Data Scientists face rapid commoditization, but opportunities surge in AI auditing and ethical model oversight.: Data Scientists are experiencing a rapid commoditization of traditional model-building because of AutoML; however, they are finding surging opportunities in AI auditing, bias detection, and ethical model oversight, commanding premiums that push salaries into the $220K range.

Customer Success professionals face pressure, with strategic 'AI-Success Orchestrators' emerging.: Customer Success professionals are facing existential pressure as tier-one troubleshooting evaporates because of the rise of AI, but new roles like strategic “AI-Success Orchestrators” are emerging at salaries upwards of $190K, centered around deep relationship management.

Anthropic's study projects significant productivity growth due to AI.: Anthropic's new study projects that even if AI progress stopped today, existing tools could lift US labor productivity by about 1.8% a year for the next decade, primarily outside of traditional tech centers in areas like admin, finance, and professional services.

Nvidia defends against claims of circular financing and accounting irregularities in a detailed memo to analysts.: Nvidia has issued a detailed memo to analysts systematically refuting bear cases regarding circular financing and accounting irregularities, although the action was seen as slightly desperate.

US controls 75% of global AI compute, posing challenges for smaller nations.: The AI landscape is becoming increasingly bipolar, with the US controlling 75% of global AI compute and China 15%, which is forcing other nations to consider sovereign AI strategies to avoid vulnerability to data exploitation and service restrictions.

Google launched Gemini 3, Nano Banana Pro and is showing optimism for Alphabet stock.: Google launched Gemini 3 with a new coding app and record benchmark scores and subsequently also launched Nano Banana Pro powered by Gemini 3, leading to optimism for Alphabet stock.
